objectives: Investigate whether the analysis of hypnopompic heart rate variability (HRV) can assist in predicting cardiovascular disease (CVD).
aims: Explore the potential value of hypnopompic HRV, especially its complexity, in the automatic prediction of CVD events.
scope: 2217 baseline CVD-free subjects were divided into groups based on the presence of CVD during follow-up.
Employ HRV measures derived from time domain, frequency domain, and nonlinear analysis to characterize cardiac functioning.
Construct machine learning models for both long-term and short-term CVD prediction based on hypnopompic HRV metrics and other typical CVD risk factors.

methods: Machine learning models were implemented using features from HRV metrics and clinical characteristics.
Used XGBoost algorithm for prediction models.
results: HRV was found to assist in predicting CVD outcomes with an accuracy of 81.4% in short-term prediction.
The complexity of hypnopompic HRV, measured by entropy-based indices, achieved greater importance in the proposed models than conventional HRV measures.
